Relative to December, there were two main factors affecting annual CPI inflation. There was a negative contribution from the transport category, given a less pronounced monthly rise in fuel prices than in January 2017. Offsetting that was a positive contribution from recreation and cultural services, admissions to attractions such as gardens and zoos in particular. The latter was a key driver of the rise in core inflation.

BE11:14am

January's lack of a decline in the CPI rate underscores our view that inflation is unlikely to fall back quickly and smoothly from here. For one, we think that the impact of the 2016 decline in sterling still has a little further to run before easing back substantially. And while energy effects have eased off recently, we expect them to pick up again somewhat over the next few months.
Continued high headline inflation notwithstanding, we think that the entirety of the 'overshoot' of the MPC's 2% target is being driven by sterling and energy effects, while underlying price pressures remain subdued. Granted, services inflation did rise from 2.5% to 2.8% y-o-y in January, but that only brings it back in line with its November rate. Indeed, services inflation still hasn't been able to break above the 3% mark and towards levels at which it prevailed before the financial crisis.

Swedish Chef Isn’t business the stuff we do? Buying & selling an’ all that?
Otter @wayneJ I like Mr. Rees-Mogg
11:15 am
BE11:15am

Today's print would have presented little news to the MPC, who predicted January inflation of 3.0% y-oy in last week's Inflation Report. The MPC's policy outlook depends on its expectation that continued strength in the labour market might eventually create excess demand in the economy, which in turn should push up on domestically-generated inflation, even as the headline rate declines gradually. For that reason, the MPC last week appeared to broadly endorse market expectations for around three further rate increases over the next three years (UK Rate announcement and Inflation Report (Feb): May very much in play, 8 February).
We take a more bearish view than the MPC though. We think the labour market might actually soften over the coming months and that wage pressures will remain contained. So while we do envisage another Bank Rate increase (from 0.50% to 0.75% in May), we do not expect any further rises through the rest of our forecast horizon, which runs to the end of 2019.

BE11:15am

And Natixis.

wayneJ @BE so if the rest of the economy is closed down and we rely on gardens and zoos our growth rate should be impressive?
BE11:17am

In both the minutes and press conference following the MPC meeting, the BoE changed significantly their communication, hinting at a more hawkish leaning and at the increased willingness to fight above-target inflation. Along with recent developments in global and domestic growth, oil prices and labour market pressures, inflation developments prompted the revision of our monetary policy forecast.
Robust foreign demand in the global economy, bolstering UK exports, have fueled into stronger-than-expected growth in 2017, with the BoE revising
upwards its 2018 GDP forecast to 1.8% (from 1.6%). The rotation of growth around exports (instead of private consumption), the perspective of overshooting inflation over a larger horizon and the steady absorption of slack in 2017 have eased the BoE’s trade-off between squeezed households’ purchasing power and growth. Consequently, the BoE is more likely to steer away from accommodative monetary policy to curb domestically-generated inflationary pressures, resulting in a “somewhat earlier and somewhat greater” monetary policy tightening. We forecast two interest rate hikes of 25bps each in May and November, although weaker-than-expected economic prospects and disruptions in Brexit negotiations would make the phasing out of tightening necessary.

Most of Inmarsat’s revenues, costs and capex are recorded in USD, except c20% of opexgenerated in the UK. The recent strength of the GBP against the USD (up 5% since mid-November) has impacted EBITDAbut this is offset bychanges in D&Aand net financial charges. This has an overall positive impact of 5% on our EPS for 2017e and no change for 2018e. Our lower GBP target price is more directlydue to USD weakness (c-5% hit through the conversion) and also a roll-over effect (balance sheet starting point becomes end-2017). Overall our new target price is 530p, down from 570p.

BE11:27am

Because of the high level of capex and inflated opex, Inmarsat’s dividend in cash is not covered. It could, however, remain at recent levels if management can demonstrate its confidence in the outlook. We believe a scrip dividend without cash would be artificial but is an option to consider, although it has not said anything on this . A cut is another, even though it would not please investors. If Ligado, the 5G project in the US that pays USD125m pa for ISAT’s spectrum, was to consider a suspension of its payments to Inmarsat, we believe Inmarsat would have no other option than to drastically cut the cash dividend (we currently assume stabilityfor the coming years).We would also consider cutting our TP by 100p per share in this scenario. Considering all these risks, we maintain our Hold rating. An update is expected on 9 March (FY17 release).

Our caution on TUI concerns increasing capital intensity required to sustain profit growth. To date that concern has been overlooked by the market as investors focus on avoiding earnings risk. Our detailed ROIC analysis shows TUI’s flattering methodology to be found wanting, with FCF insufficient to cover dividends. With no plans to contribute new capital to key JVs, off-balance sheet gearing is elevated. We question whether the ‘free lunch’ on capital can persist, and if double digit profit growth is sustainable once capex normalises; hence our SELL rating

BE11:44am

There is a lot of magic in investing, a lot of drawing pretty pictures on charts and expecting them to tell you the future. The naive view of this magic is that it is magic: The pictures have a self-operative reality; the "head and shoulders" is a supernatural spirit, telling you what your stock will do next, if you can only understand his language. The plausible, mature view is that the pictures encapsulate some real truths about human behavior: You can recast technical analysis in terms of behavioral psychology, explain resistance levels as loss aversion, and generally explain all your market signals in terms of plausible stories about humans. And you really should. You can't have much confidence in a pretty pattern just for its own sake. There is a lot of data out there. Butter production in Bangladesh was once famously well-correlated with the S&P 500 Index, but there's no reason to think it's predictive. Chief executive officer golf handicaps are also correlated with stock performance, and there is an easy human story to tell there about CEOs who spend too much time golfing and not enough time running their companies.

But deep-learning investing strategies that can't explain themselves lose that connection to plausible human stories. They feel almost like a step backwards: We thought we could explain markets in terms of human behavior, but with enough artificial intelligence maybe we can't. Maybe it's magic after all.

Despite Brent averaging merely $54/bbl last year, FCF rose to its highest level since 2009, ROACE is improving rapidly and is on track to converge to its long-run average by 2019/20, and gearing is falling steadily

Every previous cycle has shown that, in the end, commodity prices and the industry's cost structure find a new equilibrium such that new projects can go ahead again and the majors can maintain their dividends. This has been a cornerstone of our research in the last 3-4 years. Whilst we staunchly believed that dividends would not be cut, we did not forecast a return to dividend growth. Against that backdrop, dividend hikes from Total and Statoil mark an important inflection point, and are reflective of the progress that insiders are seeing
